text.p: These are some of the leading stories in the official Vietnamese press on Monday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
-- Prime Minister Vo Van Kiet has approved the upgrading of a four-lane road linking Ho Chi Minh City to the Cambodian border as part of a Trans-Asian highway.
-- Australian Foreign Minister Alexander Downer and Vietnam's Deputy Prime Minister, Phan Van Khai, on Sunday started a pile driver for the new My Thuan bridge across Mekong river.

-- A cumbersome city management structure, a banking industry reluctant to extend credit, the failure of local companies and a lack of clear development paths for state sector have been singled out as the reasons for economic slowdown in Ho Chi Minh City.
-- The Chairman of the Government Office, Lai Van Cu, said the government will continue to merge large state enterprises into strong corporations.
-- The U.S. ambassador to Vietnam, Pete Peterson, said the U.S Consulate General in Ho Chi Minh City should be fully operational by the middle of 1998.
-- Prime Minister Vo Van Kiet signed a decision limiting additional fees for telecom services charged by hotels.
-- Hanoi's Communist Party Chief has called for a new investment wave to finance for the city's five-year development plans.
-- More than 700 criminal cases have been brought to Hanoi People's Courts in June.
